metadata.sermon_title: On Not Winning the Heisman Trophy
metadata.sermon_start_end: You know how it goes now in football, both college and professional. After almost every play, some lineman rises out of the debris, waves his fist and gestures to the crowd in triumph. [...] New power, new glory, new dominion, new kingdom, world without end.
metadata.historical_context: Late 20th/Early 21st century American context, referencing the Heisman Trophy and NFL culture.
metadata.notes: The sermon employs a strong 'New Homiletic' approach, utilizing a central metaphor to bridge ancient text and modern culture.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in creating a vivid, cinematic world. Brueggemann uses the 'Heisman' and 'NFL lineman' metaphor not as a mere illustration, but as a structural lens. The imagery is tactile and sensory: 'debris' of a football play, the 'stench' of the struggle (implied), and the mundane reality of a 'three-year-old who must potty.' By juxtaposing the 'strutting' of a lineman with the 'feeble father,' he creates a sharp visual contrast between worldly glory and divine 'hesed.' The imagery effectively 'shows' the theological shift from power to vulnerability rather than just 'telling' it. It avoids religious kitsch by grounding the divine action in gritty, recognizable human commitments.
quotes: some lineman rises out of the debris, waves his fist and gestures to the crowd in triumph.
hurrying off the field because he must take his beloved three-year-old to the bathroom.
This glory comes cross-shaped, hurt-shaped, driven by vulnerability.
strengths: Strong use of 'Show, don't tell' through the football metaphor.
Effective juxtaposition of high-status (NFL) and low-status (potty training) imagery.
Concrete sensory details that make the biblical 'glory' tangible.
improvement_points: The football metaphor might be culturally exclusive for those unfamiliar with American sports.
The transition to the 'J' and 'P' source analysis is slightly more abstract than the opening imagery.
Could have utilized more sensory language regarding the 'Exodus' scene itself (the water, the wind).
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly weighted toward 'showing' through the extended metaphor of the lineman.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Brueggemann demonstrates high stewardship of language by reclaiming the word 'glory' from its clichéd religious usage. He uses precise theological terms (hesed, emeth, P source, J source) but embeds them within the narrative flow so they don't function as 'Canaanite jargon.' The language is economical; he moves quickly from the sports field to the biblical text. There is a clear 'loving care' for words, particularly in how he defines 'grace and truth' as 'fidelity and reliability.' However, the use of 'sacking Pharaoh' or 'sacking Saddam' is a bit blunt, though intentionally provocative to ground the text in political reality.
quotes: Full of hesed and ‘emeth. Full of fidelity and reliability.
Yahweh is always off the field when the scouts are watching.
The glory script... Yahweh’s behavior would be like an NFL lineman.
strengths: Precise redefinition of theological concepts using vernacular language.
Avoidance of 'stained-glass' language in favor of 'street' precision.
Clear, punchy sentence structures that emphasize core points.
improvement_points: The mention of 'Saddam' dates the sermon and might distract from the timelessness of the 'Pharaoh' archetype.
The academic 'source analysis' reference (P and J) could be more seamlessly integrated for a lay audience.
Some repetition of 'three-year-old' and 'old man' could be varied.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon is present (P/J source, hesed) but is used as a tool for precision rather than an obscuring mask.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The text has a distinct oral cadence, typical of Brueggemann’s prophetic-rhetorical style. He uses parallelism ('New power, new glory, new dominion...') and rhythmic repetitions to build intensity. The sentence length varies effectively: short, declarative sentences ('So I went.') are followed by longer, more descriptive ones. There is a 'staccato' feel in the description of the football game that transitions into a more 'legato' reflection on the nature of God. It is clearly 'spoken' language, not 'paper' language, designed to be heard and felt in the moment of performance.
quotes: He is handsome, cool, sensitive, successful. He is in every way number one; Hallelujah!
New power, new glory, new dominion, new kingdom, world without end.
The Lord will fight for you, you have only to keep still.
strengths: Excellent use of rhetorical parallelism in the conclusion.
Natural oral rhythm that avoids bureaucratic or 'paper' phrasing.
Effective use of pauses and short sentences for emphasis.
improvement_points: The transition between the football story and the source analysis (P and J) breaks the rhythmic flow slightly.
Some sentences are a bit 'breathless' and could benefit from more rhythmic variation in the middle section.
The 'Hallelujah!' feels slightly forced in the written rhythm.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Highly oral language; the text is clearly a script for a performance, not an essay.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language is characterized by a 'sober beauty' that rejects religious kitsch in favor of gritty, everyday metaphors. Brueggemann acts as a 'steward of language' by stripping the word 'glory' of its abstract, shiny veneer and reclothing it in the 'hurt-shaped' reality of human connection. The imagery is the strongest suit, using the NFL lineman as a powerful 'reframing' device. While the academic references to source theory briefly interrupt the poetic flow, the overall musicality and precision create a compelling, sensory experience for the hearer.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Homiletical Plot' as described by Eugene Lowry. It begins with an 'upsetting of the equilibrium' by challenging the standard definition of Epiphany/Glory. The tension is built through the 'lineman' metaphor—the conflict between the 'glory script' and the 'connection script.' The turning point (the 'climax') occurs when Yahweh is revealed not as the one sacking Pharaoh, but as the one present with the fearful slaves. The movement from the football field to Exodus, then to the Gospel of John, and finally to the hearer's own life creates a dynamic journey from A to B.
quotes: The Exodus story, however, sharply deviates from this glory script.
Yahweh is like that. It is remarkable that a good source analysis...
Remember this strange departure from the field, when you wave to the crowd.
strengths: Clear movement from a familiar cultural 'frame' to a disruptive biblical 'reframe'.
The 'problem' (false glory) is sustained long enough to make the 'grace' (true glory) impactful.
Strong 'upsetting' of expectations at the beginning.
improvement_points: The 'Ponder first/Ponder second' structure at the end is a bit more static than the narrative beginning.
The connection between the Heisman trophy and the 'cross-shaped' glory could be tightened.
The transition to the 'angels singing' feels slightly disconnected from the football arc.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: Dynamic journey; it moves from a cultural observation to a theological crisis and ends with a new orientation.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a textbook example of Cilliers' 'reframing.' Brueggemann takes the context (American obsession with individual success/sports) and the text (Exodus/John) and synthesizes them so that each sheds light on the other. The 'strangeness' of the biblical text is preserved—God is not just a 'winner' in the worldly sense. The integration is organic because the 'lineman' metaphor perfectly captures the tension between power and service. It doesn't just 'apply' the text; it forces the hearer to see their own 'triumphs' through the lens of God's 'vulnerable engagement.'
quotes: Yahweh is not unlike these football linemen... but the Exodus story sharply deviates.
Yahweh reidentifies the place where real glory is gotten.
The truth is we are not made in the image of a God who just sacks Pharaoh.
strengths: Authentic 'reframing' of reality through the lens of Scripture.
The biblical text is not a 'springboard' but the actual source of the disruption.
The synthesis feels surprising yet inevitable.
improvement_points: The 'Saddam' reference is a 'forced' contextualization that hasn't aged as well as the rest of the sermon.
Could have explored the 'Pharaoh' side of the context more—who are our modern Pharaohs beyond just political figures?
The 'J' and 'P' distinction might be too 'academic context' for a general liturgical setting.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Strong reframing; it offers a completely new 'optics' for understanding divine and human glory.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: While the sermon is rhetorically powerful, it leans toward a 'closed' structure in its moral application. Brueggemann is a 'witness' (Long), but his witness is very directive. The 'Ponder first/second' section tells the hearer exactly what to think. However, the central image of the 'lineman leaving the field' is an 'open work of art' (Stark) that allows the hearer to imagine their own 'departures' from glory. The ending is a liturgical doxology, which 'seals' the sermon dogmatically, but the 'cross-shaped glory' remains a mystery that the hearer must live out.
quotes: Ponder this first: Yahweh struggles for a new notion of glory.
Remember this strange departure from the field, when you wave to the crowd.
The glory to which we are invited... is of another sort.
strengths: The central metaphor is polyvalent and allows for personal appropriation.
The sermon avoids 'easy' happy endings by emphasizing 'vulnerability' and 'risk'.
The 'Heisman' metaphor leaves a lingering question about the hearer's own trophies.
improvement_points: The 'Ponder first/second' structure is a bit didactic and 'seals' the interpretation.
Could leave more room for the hearer to struggle with the difficulty of 'leaving the field'.
The conclusion is quite prescriptive ('Remember this...').
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Mixed; the imagery is open and polyvalent, but the structural application is relatively monovalent and directive.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic is dominated by a powerful narrative arc that successfully 'reframes' the concept of Epiphany. Brueggemann moves the hearer from the 'crowd' in the stadium to the 'fearful slaves' in the mud, creating a palpable dramaturgical shift. While the final section becomes somewhat didactic with its 'ponder' points, the overall structure functions as a 'happening' where the definition of glory is dismantled and rebuilt. It avoids the static three-point sermon in favor of a dynamic movement between the 'glory script' and the 'connection script'.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is a masterclass in avoiding religious kitsch. Brueggemann intentionally takes 'shiny' religious concepts (Glory, Epiphany, Hallelujah) and drags them through the 'debris' of a football field and the 'potty' needs of a child. This is the opposite of kitsch; it is the 'beauty of the cross.' He refuses to offer a 'happy ending' where the lineman wins the Heisman *and* helps his father. Instead, the lineman *misses* the glory. By choosing 'vulnerability' and 'hurt-shaped' glory over 'strutting,' he honors the 'ambivalence of existence' (Stark) and the 'pain of suffering' (Cilliers).
examples_of_kitsch: The potential kitsch of 'angels singing' is immediately grounded in 'peace on earth' to avoid sentimentalism.
The 'Hallelujah' is used ironically or at least subverted by the 'cross-shaped' reality.
authentic_moments: The description of the lineman leaving the peak of his glory for a mundane, 'un-glamorous' task.
The definition of glory as 'hurt-shaped' and 'driven by vulnerability'.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Continue to use 'low' imagery to subvert 'high' theological concepts to maintain this high level of authenticity.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon opens a significant 'Space for Grace' by redefining God's power as 'relatedness.' Following Cilliers, Brueggemann moves between 'despair' (the fearful slaves) and 'hope' (the rescue), but he does not resolve the tension cheaply. Grace is found in the 'between'—in the commitment to the 'feeble' and the 'needy.' By portraying God as a 'connected God' who is 'at risk,' he creates a space where the hearer's own vulnerabilities are not obstacles to grace but the very location of it. The mystery of the 'cross-shaped glory' is respected and held open.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between the 'crowd's applause' and the 'beloved folks' is sustained throughout the sermon.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'oddness' and 'strangeness' of God's glory are preserved; it is not fully 'explained away' but presented as a new reality to inhabit.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: While there is a moral call to be 'made in this image,' it is grounded in the prior 'grace and truth' of God's own character.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To open even more space, the preacher could invite the hearer into the 'silence' mentioned in the Exodus text ('you have only to keep still').

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of the 'New Homiletic' and 'Reframing.' Brueggemann’s primary aesthetic achievement is the radical subversion of 'Glory' through a mundane, even 'low,' cultural metaphor. By using the NFL lineman, he avoids the 'aestheticism' of beautiful but empty language, instead opting for a 'sober beauty' that is transparent toward the character of God. The poetics of language are strong, characterized by oral rhythm and precise redefinitions of biblical terms. The dramaturgy is effective, leading the hearer on a journey from the 'stadium' of worldly success to the 'margin' of divine fidelity. The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch, choosing the 'stench' of real life over the 'perfume' of easy comfort. It successfully opens 'Space for Grace' by identifying God’s glory with God’s 'at-risk' relatedness to the vulnerable.
strengths_top_3: The 'Heisman/NFL Lineman' metaphor as a powerful reframing device.
The complete absence of religious kitsch through the use of 'low' imagery.
The precise and rhythmic 'stewardship of language' in redefining 'glory'.
improvement_points_top_3: The didactic 'Ponder first/second' structure at the end reduces the 'openness' of the work.
The academic 'source analysis' (P/J) could be more poetically integrated.
The political references (Saddam) date the sermon and slightly narrow its aesthetic reach.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Anti-kitsch) and Paul Scott Wilson (Imagery/Four Pages).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Hearers who are weary of 'triumphalist' religion and those who live in high-pressure 'success' cultures (like the US) will find this aesthetically and spiritually resonant.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an even more 'open' ending that leaves the hearer in the 'silence' of the Exodus rescue.
Try to weave 'academic' insights (like source theory) into the narrative imagery rather than stating them as 'analysis'.
Explore the sensory details of the 'biblical' side of the metaphor as deeply as the 'cultural' side.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: A high-quality sermon that demonstrates how aesthetic form (the lineman metaphor) can become the content (the nature of God's glory). It is a 'strong' aesthetic performance that avoids the pitfalls of sentimentality and jargon, offering instead a 'vulnerable' and 'connected' vision of the divine that is both challenging and deeply comforting. It serves as a model for 'reframing' ancient texts for a contemporary, success-driven audience.
